page.title: 17Railways & Victoria Viaduct
page.content: After the Civil War a series of {"Waggon Ways"}built by local coal owners such as Lambton led from the emerging pits at Philadelphia and Penshaw to the river Wear so that coal could be sent by boat to Sunderland. One of the last remaining railwaylines today joins Herrington Colliery with the Lambton Cokeworks and follows part of one of these old Waggon Ways. The{Victoria Viaduct}was one of the wonders of the early{railway age.}It is made of stone and has four main arched spans and six small spans. It was built of local freestone found in Penshaw quarries. It was said to have the largest arch in Europe at the time of building and stands 128ft above the River Wear just north of Penshaw. It received its name because the last stone was laid on the day of Queen Victoria's Coronation.
